Why does my Heart beat fast after Smoking?

Dr. Mansi
September 28, 2024

Table of Contents

Are you a smoker? Have you ever noticed your heart racing like a car after a smoke break, leaving you to wonder, “Why does my heart beat fast after smoking?” You’re not alone in this experience, and understanding it is crucial for your health.

In this blog, we’ll delve into the science behind why does my heart beat fast after smoking, explore the potential risks involved, and discuss ways to manage these symptoms. Whether you’re looking for answers or seeking to make healthier choices, you’ve come to the right place. Let’s take a closer look at the impact of smoking on your heart and what you can do about it.

Why does my heart beat fast after smoking?

When considering why does my heart beat fast after smoking,It’s critical to comprehend the consequences of the dangerous substances found in cigarettes. Cigarettes include benzene and arsenic among other dangerous substances. Smoking causes the inhalation of carbon monoxide, a poisonous gas that has no color or odor and can be fatal.

Nicotine is the most well-known of the many harmful compounds that smoking brings into the body. This stimulant causes a variety of physiological reactions in addition to its effects on the neurological system. Upon entering the bloodstream, nicotine swiftly travels to the brain, where it triggers the release of several neurotransmitters. The release of adrenaline, which sets off the body’s “fight or flight” reaction and raises heart rate, is one of the main effects.

Tobacco smoke is made up of thousands of chemicals, including:

  • Nicotine: It is highly addictive, affects how the brain and muscles perform, and increases blood pressure, which makes the heart work harder.
  • Carbon monoxide: a dangerous gas that lowers the bloodstream’s oxygen flow to the heart and other organs by displacing oxygen.
  • Tar: a sticky substance that makes breathing harder by building up in the lungs. Tar also includes a lot of compounds that cause cancer.

The Heart's Response to Nicotine

Now that you understand why does my heart beat fast after smoking, let’s delve deeper into the heart’s response to nicotine. Nicotine has several direct effects on the cardiovascular system that contribute to the changes you experience. We can better understand how nicotine affects heart health and function by looking at these consequences. The heart’s primary reactions to nicotine are as follows:

Increased heart rate: In the short term, nicotine can raise heart rate by up to 20 beats per minute, and over the course of the day, it can do so by an average of 7 beats per minute.

Narrowed arteries: Nicotine has the ability to narrow arteries, which restricts blood flow and increases cardiac workload.

Myocardial ischemia: Nicotine alters the heart’s oxygen and nutrition balance, which can result in acute myocardial ischemia. 

Increased risk of heart attack: Nicotine’s impact on the heart can raise the likelihood of a heart attack.

Increased blood pressure: Blood pressure rises when adrenaline is released by the adrenal glands as a result of nicotine.

Why does my Heart beat fast after Smoking?

By activating the sympathetic nervous system and causing the production of norepinephrine, which quickens heartbeats, nicotine increases heart rate. This happens via a number of mechanisms:

  • Central nervous system activation: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) in the brain are activated by nicotine.
  • Increased blood pressure: Blood pressure can rise by 5 – 10 mm Hg when using nicotine.
  • Systemic vasoconstriction: Nicotine increases cardiac output by constricting blood vessels.
  • Peripheral nervous system activation: It also triggers nAChRs in the peripheral nervous system, such as those in the carotid chemoreceptor.

Risks due to smoking

Smoking significantly increases the risk of heart disease through several mechanisms. Here’s how it affects cardiovascular health:

1. Damage to Blood Vessels

Tobacco smoke contains compounds that harm blood vessel endothelial linings, causing inflammation and increasing the risk of atherosclerosis in arteries. Blood flow gets restricted and the narrowing of arteries results from this injury.

2. Increased Plaque Buildup

Smoking increases bad cholesterol (LDL) and decreases good cholesterol (HDL), which leads to the buildup of plaque in the arteries. This accumulation raises the possibility of blockages, which can result in strokes and heart attacks.

3. Elevated Heart Rate and Blood Pressure

Nicotine increases blood pressure and heart rate, which puts more strain on the cardiovascular system. This can eventually result in high blood pressure and other heart-related problems.

4. Enhanced Clot Formation

Smoking makes platelets stickier, which increases the likelihood that blood may clot. This increases the chance of blood clots, or thrombosis, which can block blood flow and result in pulmonary embolism or heart attacks.

5. Reduced Oxygen Supply

Smoke-derived carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells, decreasing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the cells. This makes the heart work harder, which raises the possibility of harm and cardiac-related incidents.

6. Chronic Inflammation

Smoking causes chronic inflammation in the body, which can result in cardiovascular disease and accelerate the development of atherosclerosis.

Side Effects of Smoking

Smoking cigarettes has numerous harmful side effects that affect nearly every part of the body. Here’s a summary of some of the most significant effects:

  • Lung cancer
  • Chronic bronchitis
  • Emphysema
  • Heart disease
  • Stroke
  • Reduced fertility
  • Premature aging
  • Weakened immune system
  • Respiratory infections
  • Oral cancer
  • Throat cancer
  • Gum disease
  • Bad breath
  • Yellowed teeth
  • Skin damage

How Do I Quit Smoking?

Quitting smoking requires a variety of tactics to boost your chances of success. Begin by establishing a quit date and eliminating cigarettes and triggers from your environment. To help with cravings, consider adopting nicotine replacement therapy such as patches or gum. Participate in support groups or counseling to discuss your experiences and get motivated. Identify triggers and develop healthy coping strategies, such as exercise or hobbies. 

Stay committed by keeping track of your progress and recognizing milestones. Finally, keep in mind that setbacks are normal, do not give up and keep trying. With determination and the correct help, you can successfully quit smoking forever

Understanding why does my heart beat fast after smoking is essential for recognizing the impact of smoking on your cardiovascular health. The combination of nicotine’s stimulating effects and the harmful substances in cigarettes can lead to increased heart rate, elevated blood pressure, and a host of long-term health risks. 

By acknowledging these effects, you can take important steps toward making healthier choices and prioritizing your well-being. If you’ve ever found yourself asking, why does my heart beat fast after smoking, consider seeking support to quit and improve your overall health. Quitting smoking can lead to a healthier heart and a better quality of life.
